Search the community to find answers for issues just like yours
If you still need help, post a topic in the community
support.alt.step_select_zone.technical.d: Select a **Domain** and describe your issue in the **Summary** box to get self-service content suggestions and run our automated diagnostics. For technical issues, users on our Free plan have access to our self-service support content as well as our Community. If you wish to submit a ticket for 1:1 support from Cloudflare, you must upgrade your plan type.

support.alt.step_related_content.account:
Most of our customers are able to resolve their issues utilizing our self-service content.

Adding a new domain or site to your account?
Read this short guide or watch the video on adding a site to Cloudflare.

Do you want to grant another person access to manage your account?
Our guide Managing members shows you how to add or revoke access for other users to manage your account.

Do you want to change your Cloudflare plan?
You can do this in the dashboard today by following change plan type.

Want to delete your account?
You can do this instantly today by following delete your Cloudflare account.
support.alt.step_related_content.billing:
Most of our customers are able to resolve their issues utilizing our self-service content.

Solve your failed payment issue right now.
Follow our guide to the most Common Reasons for Failed Payment.

Cancelling your paid subscription?
It just takes 2 easy steps to cancel your subscription.

Questions about your invoice?
We recommend reading Understanding Cloudflare invoices.

Changing your Billing address or adding VAT/GST information?
You can do this immediately via our dashboard by following Updating Billing Information.
support.alt.step_related_content.footer: Still need help? Click Next to provide more details about your issue.
support.alt.step_related_content.registr:
Most of our customers are able to resolve their issues utilizing our self-service content.

Transferring a domain to Cloudflare Registrar?
Make sure your domain is in our list of Supported TLDs and if it is, follow our step by step guide to Domain Transfers.

Are you attempting to transfer out of Cloudflare Registrar?
Follow the Transfer out from Cloudflare guide.

Renewing a domain?
Follow our renewing domains guide here. Always make sure your chosen payment method has not rejected any charges from us and then you can retry a manual renewal.

If you can't find what you're looking for, consider asking your question on the [Cloudflare Community](https://community.cloudflare.com/). You can also view domain diagnostics on the [Error Analytics](/%{accountId}/support/error-analytics) page.

support.error_analytics.title: Error Analytics
support.error_analytics.help:
The **Errors Over Time** graph and the **Top Requests** details are based on a 1% traffic sample.

The **Requests** column shows the number of HTTP Status Codes served. **Error Rate** column shows the percentage of all requests. For example, for 50 requests returning HTTP Error 502 out of 10,000 requests in 24-hours, the Error Rate for HTTP 502 errors is 0.5%.

Find help to diagnose and resolve 5XX errors for Cloudflare proxied sites at [Troubleshooting Cloudflare 5XX errors](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115003011431).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.desc: To help you identify common issues
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.clie: The origin web server for %{zoneName} is returning a HTTP [4xx client error](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115003014512). Cloudflare does not generate these error messages. Contact your hosting provider for help.

The origin web server for %{zoneName} is returning a high percentage of HTTP [4xx client errors](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115003014512). Cloudflare does not generate these error messages. Contact your hosting provider for help.
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.cnam: Since you have a CNAME set-up, you need to add a verification TXT record to your authoritative DNS before Cloudflare can activate your domain. We couldn't find a valid verification DNS record for %{zoneName}. Review [Configuring a CNAME setup](https://developers.cloudflare.com/dns/zone-setups/partial-setup).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.dns_: You are missing DNS records for your domain root (%{zoneName}) or the www subdomain (www.%{zoneName}). You'll see [err_name_not_resolved errors](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/217912538) when accessing a (sub)domain with missing DNS records. Review [Managing DNS records in Cloudflare](https://developers.cloudflare.com/dns/manage-dns-records/how-to/create-dns-records).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.mixe: %{zoneName} has mixed content errors. Mixed content disrupts content delivery over HTTPS because some of the resources requested are served over HTTP. If this error occurs, a green lock does not appear when serving HTTPS traffic. Review [How do I fix the SSL Mixed Content Error Message?](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/200170476).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.name: The authoritative nameservers for %{zoneName} are set incorrectly. For Cloudflare to activate, your domain registrar must point to the two nameservers provided by Cloudflare as the authoritative servers. Set your authoritative nameservers in your registrar's admin panel (contact your registrar for support). Review [changing your nameservers](https://developers.cloudflare.com/dns/zone-setups/full-setup).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.redi: %{zoneName} has a redirect loop error. This error often leads to website downtime and has two common causes: an incorrect SSL setting or forced HTTPS redirects., review our guide on [troubleshooting redirect loops](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115000219871).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.serv: %{zoneName} is returning a HTTP 5xx server error. Review [5xx Server Error](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115003011431).
%{zoneName} is returning a high percentage of HTTP 5xx server errors Review [5xx Server Error](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115003011431).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.slow: The origin web server for %{zoneName} is responding slowly to initial requests for uncached HTML content. To remove this performance bottleneck, look at your server's ability to return HTML faster and/or implement HTML caching in Cloudflare. You may benefit from [caching static HTML and anonymous page views](https://developers.cloudflare.com/cache/best-practices/customize-cache). Learn how to do this in: [WordPress](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/236166048), [Drupal](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115002911927) and [Magento](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/236168808).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.ssl_: %{zoneName} does not have a valid SSL certificate. It may take up to 24 hours to issue a new SSL certificate. Make sure that the domain is correctly set up in Cloudflare. Review [Why isn't SSL working for my site?](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/200170566).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.stat: %{zoneName} is returning a significant percentage of HTTP 5xx server errors. Check Server Error Report here and review [5xx Server Error](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115003011431).

support.phone_support.description:
In the event of a critical issue, Enterprise customers may contact our 24x7 emergency hotline. Regional numbers for the emergency hotline can be found on the [Enterprise Portal](https://cloudflare.com/ecp/support).

To help us verify your identity, click a button to generate:
* a single-use token per call, or
* an authenticator app token on your mobile device. You can use a two-factor app like Google Authenticator.

support.forgot_email.description: This tool helps determine the email address associated to your Cloudflare account. Provide your active Cloudflare domain in the form below to email the address on file. Enterprise customers cannot utilize this tool and must contact their Customer Success Manager.

support.forgot_email.registered:
Thank you for providing those details. If that domain is active on Cloudflare, we have notified the email address on file. If you haven't received an email after 20 minutes, check your spam folder. The message will be sent from 'no-reply@cloudflare.com' or 'noreply@notify.cloudflare.com'. If you can't find the email, you can start the recovery process again or enter a different domain in your account.

If you have lost access to the original email address used to sign up for your Cloudflare account, review the following article: u201C[I lost the email address associated with my Cloudflare account, what do I do?](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/203471284#12345681)u201D

support.step_diagnostics.backlog_message:
Dear valued customer,

Due to the current global pandemic crisis, Cloudflare has seen a large increase in Internet traffic through our network, and is experiencing a large increase in customer ticket volume. This has resulted in longer than normal delays in inquiry response. We apologize for this delay and inconvenience. If your question is not urgent or high priority, in lieu of submitting a ticket, please consult our extensive [knowledge base](https://support.cloudflare.com/), [developer docs](https://developers.cloudflare.com/), and [community](https://community.cloudflare.com/) to find the answer to your question. This is the fastest way for quick assistance with general questions.  However, if your request is urgent or high priority, please submit a ticket for support.

Thanks for your understanding and help.

Cloudflare Customer Support Team
support.step_diagnostics.texas_backlog_m:

This is the fastest way for quick assistance with general questions.  However, if your request is urgent or high priority, please submit a ticket for support.

Thanks for your understanding and help.

Cloudflare Customer Support Team

support.portal.self-help-wizard.dns.name: I have a question about Nameservers
Is the domain in question already active in your account?
**To check if your domain is active** * Visit the Cloudflare dashboard * Type in your domain name * Do you see "Active" underneath the domain name?
Do you want to change your nameservers to another provider?
Are you a Cloudflare Registrar customer?

To check if you are Cloudflare Registrar customer: Visit Cloudflare Dashboard and find your domain. On the domain overview page on the right hand side under "Domain Registration" you will see "Registrar: Cloudflare" if you are a Cloudflare Registrar customer.
Follow the Transfer domain from Cloudflare to another registrar guide to proceed.

As Cloudflare is your DNS provider only, you can switch to another service by visiting your domain registrar Note if you switch away, you will lose all of the benefits of Cloudflare except if you choose Partial (CNAME) Setup

support.portal.self-help-wizard.403.four: I'm getting an HTTP Error 403
Is the domain on which youu2019re getting the error 403 part of your Cloudflare account?
You can find the list of zones that you manage in the home page of your Cloudflare Dashboard.
Is the 403 error page a Cloudflare branded error page or a Custom Error Page you have configured?
Custom Error Pages can be created at the zone or account level.
Is the error presented with a white page containing only `403 Forbidden - Cloudflare`?
Does the 403 error page mention `Cloudflare` at all?
Is the error reported by a bot, crawler or external service such as Google?
Error 403 may be reported in the Google Search Console, Bing Webmaster Tools or similar services.
Are you getting this 403 error in a browser?
Have you confirmed that you see the `server: cloudflare` header in the HTTP response youu2019re getting?
You can use the `curl` command line tool with the `-v` option to get more details on the response headers, see our documentation here.

This means that the request was not proxied by Cloudflare, and that the 403 error is served by your origin web server. Youu2019ll need to check the access log and security features on your origin web server. The following resources might help: - NGINX Security Controls - Apache Security Tips You might need help from your website administrator or hosting provider. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

Since the error is not Cloudflare branded but is being returned via Cloudflare, this means that the HTTP 403 response was returned by your origin server and proxied through Cloudflare. Youu2019ll need to check the access log and security features on your origin web server. The following resources might help: - NGINX Security Controls - Apache Security Tips You might need help from your website administrator or hosting provider. If the Cloudflare zone is on the Enterprise plan, you can use the Cloudlfare Logs to get more details about the request. You can confirm using the field `OriginResponseStatus` if the 403 response code is returned by your origin. You can check the Security Events on your Cloudflare Dashboard to check for request blocked or challenged by Cloudflare Security features. If necessary, use the Skip action to exclude specific URLs from rule application.

Please review the headers and the content of the error page, and check again whether this is a Cloudflare branded error or not. You can use the Developer Tools in your browser to get more details about the request. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

Cloudflare by default allows verified bots. You can check your Security Events in your Cloudflare Dashboard under Security -> Events to make sure you are not blocking or challenging Google bots (or other relevant crawling bots). If necessary, use the Skip action to exclude specific URLs or specific bots from rule application. If the Cloudflare zone is on the Enterprise plan, you can use the Cloudlfare Logs to get more details about the request. You can confirm using the field `OriginResponseStatus` if the 403 response code is returned by your origin.

In this case the error 403 is served by your origin web server. Youu2019ll need to check the access log and security features on your origin web server. The following resources might help: - NGINX Security Controls - Apache Security Tips You might need help from your website administrator or hosting provider. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

A blank page with `403 Forbidden - Cloudflare` in the body can be caused by a mismatch between the host header and requested host (URI). Please check that you are requesting the expected hostname, and that this hostname is configured on the Subject Alternative Name (SAN) of the certificate presented by Cloudflare. If you're using a proxy or load balancer in between the affected clients and Cloudflare, you might need to review the SNI configuration of these applications. Please also note that local endpoint security applications (like antivirus) might affect the connection from a client to Cloudflare as they might install a local root certificate to be able to decrypt and analyze traffic. Please also check that your browser is supported and that you're using a supported cipher suite. The openssl tool might be helpful to try to reproduce the issue and investigate further on your side: `openssl s_client -connect :443 -servername `

In this case a Cloudflare security feature has blocked or challenged the request. Youu2019ll need to check the Security Events in your Cloudflare Dashboard under Security -> Events. If necessary, use the Skip action to exclude specific URLs from rule application. If you need assistance configuring the WAF Managed Rules, please select the Technical - Website -> Security category to get further assistance in our Support Portal. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

If you are being blocked or challenged, please get in touch with the website owner to inquire for the specific reason. There are several common reasons a Cloudflare-protected website may block or challenge a site visitor: - The visitoru2019s IP address demonstrated previous suspicious activity online. Review your client IP address for malicious activity at Project Honeypot. - The website owner is using the Web Application Firewall (WAF) to block or challenge specific requests. - The visitoru2019s actions triggered a WAF Managed Rules enabled by the website owner.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.404.four: When you test on your origin web server directly, do you also get a 404?
If needed you can pause Cloudflare temporarily to check the response without the request getting proxied by Cloudflare.
Do you see the `server: cloudflare` header in the HTTP response youu2019re getting?
You can use the Developer Tools in your browser or the `curl` command line tool with the `-v` option to get more details on the response headers, see our documentation here.
Have you confirmed that the 404 response is coming from the expected origin web server?

You can check the DNS configuration of your hostname in the Cloudflare Dashboard under DNS -> Records, and you might need to review your origin configuration (Load Balancers, proxies) and access logs.
Do you see the `CF-Cache-Status: HIT` header in the HTTP response youu2019re getting?
You can use the Developer Tools in your browser or the `curl` command line tool with the `-v` option to get more details on the response headers, see our documentation here.

Cloudflare does not generate 404 errors, so this would indicate something is not configured correctly on your origin web server. It's possible that a document root with your origin is pointed to the wrong hostname or a different working directory. You should be able to find these 404 errors in the access logs of your origin web server. The following resources might help: - NGINX Logs - Apache Logs You might need help from your website administrator or hosting provider. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

In this case the 404 error is being served from Cloudflare's Cache. Youu2019ll need to make sure that the origin web server is not returning the error anymore for this URL, and then you'll need to purge the cache. By default, Cloudflare caches 404 response codes. You might want to return the header `Cache-Control: no-cache` for such responses, so that a 404 response will not get cached on Cloudflare as the Origin Cache Control headers are respected. You might need help from your website administrator or hosting provider.

If the request is not reaching the expected origin web server you might get a 404 response code. Please make sure that the DNS record configured under DNS -> Records on the Cloudflare Dashboard for the request hostname has the expected value. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

This means that the request was not proxied by Cloudflare. The 404 error is served by your origin web server. Youu2019ll need to check the access log on your origin web server. The following resources might help: - NGINX Logs - Apache Logs You might need help from your website administrator or hosting provider. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

Please check the configuration and access logs on your origin web server. You might need to contact your hosting provider or website administrator to check these details. If needed you can pause Cloudflare temporarily to check the response without the request getting proxied by Cloudflare. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.520.five: Do you see any errors in your origin server logs?

Check that there are no errors or signs of crash in your origin web server application logs. You can find some information here about logs on Apache and here about logs on NGINX. You might need to contact your hosting provider or website administrator to check these details.
Are your origin response headers lower than 16kb?
Please note that cookies are counted as header. You can use your browser developer tools or curl to check headers.
Does your application and server return a valid HTTP response code?

The most common cause of a HTTP 520 error is the origin server resetting the TCP connection during the response. Cloudflare cannot know why your origin server does this, only your origin server hosting provider or server administrator can inform you further.

We recommend that you contact them and carefully check the origin server health and error logs when this happens to understand why a TCP reset may be occurring.

The HTTP Error 520 means that the origin server returned an empty, unknown, or unexpected response to Cloudflare, read our Troubleshooting Cloudflare 5XX Errors article for more details.

Please make sure that a valid HTTP response is returned at all times by your origin. The HTTP Error 520 means that the origin server returned an empty, unknown, or unexpected response to Cloudflare, read our Troubleshooting Cloudflare 5XX Errors article for more details.

Please check and make sure the total size of the headers is lower than 16kb. The HTTP Error 520 means that the origin server returned an empty, unknown, or unexpected response to Cloudflare, read our Troubleshooting Cloudflare 5XX Errors article for more details.

Please check and make sure your application is stable and does not return unexpected errors. The HTTP Error 520 means that the origin server returned an empty, unknown, or unexpected response to Cloudflare, read our Troubleshooting Cloudflare 5XX Errors article for more details.

Are you using the Full, Full (Strict) or Strict (SSL-Only Origin Pull) SSL Mode?
You can check under SSL/TLS -> Overview on the Cloudflare Dashboard, see this article on SSL Modes.
Do you have a firewall configured at the origin to only allow specific IPs?

In this case Cloudflare will connect to your origin on port 443
IP access can be controlled directly on the origin web server, on or the network side. You might need to contact your hosting provider or website administrator to check these details.
Do you allow all Cloudflare IP ranges on the firewall?

All Cloudflare IP ranges need to be allowed so that Cloudflare can connect to your origin web server on port 443. The Traceroute API endpoint might help you test the connectivity between Cloudflare and your origin. (Test with tcp as packet_type and 443 as port)
Can you connect to the origin web server directly on port 443?

Check whether you are able to connect to your origin web server directly using a web browser or an SSH connection.

You might need to contact your hosting provider or website administrator to get further assistance.

In this case the connection from Cloudflare should also work. Please double-check your Firewall settings. The Error 521 occurs when the origin web server refuses connections from Cloudflare. Security solutions at your origin may block legitimate connections from certain Cloudflare IP addresses. Read our Troubleshooting Cloudflare 5XX Errors article for more details.

support.portal.self-help-wizard.bfm.opt-: Having issues with Bot Management or Bot Fight Mode?
Answer some simple questions and receive an immediate solution. Note: If your site is under a DDoS attack, please choose our 'DDoS / Under Attack' category.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.bfm.enab: I am having trouble enabling Bot Fight Mode or Super Bot Fight Mode

**To check if your domain has Bot Fight Mode enabled:** - Go to **Security** > Bots - For Bot Fight Mode, select **On** **To check if your domain has Super Bot Fight Mode enabled:** * Go to **Security** > **Bots** > Configure Super Bot Fight Mode * Change the action for each rule as needed
support.portal.self-help-wizard.bfm.anal: I am having trouble analyzing and finding bot related actions

**For Bot Fight Mode:** * Go to **Security** > Events * In the **Service** field, filter by **Bot Fight Mode** **For Super Bot Fight Mode:** * Go to **Security** > Events * In the **Service** field, filter by **Managed rules** **Note**: All requests blocked or challenged by bot can be seen. This allows to observe, analyze, and follow trends in your bot traffic over time.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.bfm.fp: Bot Fight Mode or Super Bot Fight Mode is causing problems with my application traffic (e.g. false positive)
support.portal.self-help-wizard.bfm.fp.f: Due to the high security threshold, false positives do sometimes happen. If you turned on Bot Fight Mode or Super Bot Fight Mode during an attack, and the attack has subsided, we recommend either disabling the feature, use IP access rules to bypass Bot Fight Mode (BFM will be disabled if there are any IP access rules present), or upgrade to Bot Management for Enterprise. **How to disable BFM/SBFM feature?** * For Free plan, toggle the **Bot Fight Mode** option to **Off** under **Security** > Bots * For Pro, Business and Enterprise (no Bot Management add-on) plans: use the **Skip** action in Custom Rules to specify where Super Bot Fight Mode should not run. Skip rules are only available to customers who have migrated from Custom Rules to Firewall Rules.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.bfm.allo: I run a good bot and want for it to be added to the allowlist

Cloudflare maintains a sample list of verified bots in Cloudflare Radar. To get a good-bot verified and added to the allowed list, submit the Bot Verification Form. **Must read**: In order to be listed by Cloudflare as a Verified Bot, your bot must conform to the requirements in the Cloudflare Verified Bots Policy.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.firewall: Are you having issues with Firewall Rules?
Follow quick instructions and receive an immediate solution.
I am adding Allow and Bypass rules in Firewall rules, but it's not working, why?

**Using Allow and Bypass actions:** Firewall Rules support the **Allow** and **Bypass** actions, often used together. These actions are commonly used for handling known legitimate requests u2014 for example, requests coming from trusted IP addresses. **Important Note:** You cannot bypass the new WAF managed rules using the **Bypass** action, only the previous version of WAF managed rules. Review the supported actions table on how to use Allow and Bypass actions. **Using Skip action:** Custom Rules support the **Skip** action instead, which combines the **Allow** and **Bypass** actions. With the **Skip** action you can do the following: * Stop running all the remaining custom rules (equivalent to the **Allow** action) * Avoid running other security products (equivalent to the **Bypass** action) * A combination of the above.
I see an error 1020: Access denied when visiting a site
The common cause is: a client or browser is blocked by a Cloudflare customeru2019s Firewall Rules. To resolve this issue, follow the instructions in this article.
I don't want any traffic outside of Port 80 or 443

It is expected that these ports are open on Layer 4 on our Cloudflare IP addresses that Cloudflare owns and operates, and shares between multiple customers. With the Firewall rule using **cf.edge.server_port** it is ensured at Layer 7 that **no requests to these ports will actually reach your origin, which is being protected**. You cannot control access or listeners of our Cloudflare Anycast IPs themselves with zone features such as WAF rules. What the rules you created are affecting is traffic to **your origin server**, e.g. the Firewall rule you created will block any web request passing through Cloudflare trying to access any port other than 80/443 for your domain. In order to make this judgement in a WAF rule, it is imperative that a client first connects to the port on our Edge, performs the TLS handshake and sends the HTTP request to a URL of this port. Before this we have no way of knowing which domain the client is actually trying to perform the request for. Keep in mind the Cloudflare CDN and WAF are L7 application layer features and do not operate on L3/L4. Please also note that public Cloudflare IP addresses may be shared with different customers and are not dedicated to a specific domain or customer. For more details on how to create the rule, check this documentation.
Why isnu2019t my regular expression pattern matching working?

If you are using a regular expression, it is recommended that you test it with a tool like Regular Expressions 101 or Rustexp. Also, note that the **http.request.method** field requires all-caps for method names (for example, POST).

I'm seeing requests blocked or challenged by 'Inbound Anomaly Exceeded', how do I fix?

If you see **Rule ID: OWASP Block (981176)** in **Security Events > Activity log**, then Managed Rules (Previous version) blocked it. To reduce false positives, lower the OWASP sensitivity in Package: OWASP ModSecurity Core Rule Set card. If you seexA0**Rule ID: 949110: Inbound Anomaly Score Exceeded**xA0in **Security Events > Activity log**, then Managed Rules (new version) blocked it. To reduce false positives, lower the OWASP Anomaly Score Threshold or Paranoia Level.
I am adding Allow and Bypass rules in Firewall rules, but it's not working, why?

**Using Allow and Bypass actions:** Firewall Rules support the **Allow** and **Bypass** actions, often used together. These actions are commonly used for handling known legitimate requests u2014 for example, requests coming from trusted IP addresses. **Important Note:** You cannot bypass the new WAF managed rules using the **Bypass** action, only the previous version of WAF managed rules. Review the supported actions table on how to use Allow and Bypass actions. **Using Skip action:** Custom Rules support the **Skip** action instead, which combines the **Allow** and **Bypass** actions. With the **Skip** action you can do the following: * Stop running all the remaining custom rules (equivalent to the **Allow** action) * Avoid running other security products (equivalent to the **Bypass** action) * A combination of the above.
I want to check if certain vulnerabilities or CVEs are blocked by WAF/Managed rules

**If your domain is using the Managed Rules (new version):** - Go to Cloudflare OWASP Core Ruleset - Search for the CVE number (e.g. cve-2019-8943 or cve-2020) **If your domain is using the Managed Rules (Previous version):** * Go to Managed Rules * Under the **Cloudflare Managed Ruleset** card, click on the **Advanced** link * Search for the CVE number (e.g. cve-2019-8943 or cve-2020) **If the CVE is listed:** You can confirm whether or not the rulesets are active and which action they currently take, and make any changes to the **Action** or **Status** if necessary. **If the CVE is NOT listed:** * Older CVEs may not be in scope. We will only create rules for vulnerabilities with at least a **CVSS Attack Vector (AV)** of **NETWORK** with an exploit that **specifically uses HTTP/HTTPS** * Newer CVEs may not be disclosed/may lack sufficient information for Cloudflare to take action As information develops, these new CVEs will be reevaluated by our engineers. **What can I do if a CVE is not currently mitigated by the Cloudflare Managed Ruleset?** We currently only update our managed rule sets with recent CVEs or with CVEs that are affecting software components that are widely in use. If you believe this vulnerability meets this criteria, please continue to sumbit a ticket for further investigation. Otherwise, we advise you to build a custom Firewall rule. Check this documentation on how to build a custom Firewall rule. We aim to provide managed WAF rules that are generally applicable to our wide customer base to ensure that our WAF also has a very low false positive rate. Custom Firewall Rules are meant to be used to expand on that generally applicable coverage.

support.portal.self-help-wizard.billing_: Payment failure
Is your payment failing?
If you're having trouble paying for a Cloudflare invoice or upgrade, check here for immediate answers.
My payment is failing with Cloudflare

If youu2019re unable to add a payment method due to an error, or a specific payment is failing when you attempt to pay or renew, please try the following: **1. Check you are using a supported payment method** Review our Approved Payment Methods - Cloudflare only accepts VISA, MasterCard, American Express, Discover, Paypal, and UnionPay. No other payment methods (for example, Maestro) are possible at this time. **2. Retry the payment in an incognito or private browser** Some browser extensions or configurations can interfere with your payment processing. We recommend retrying the payment in your browseru2019s *private* or *incognito* mode. This will ensure no extensions can interfere with the process. **3. Check the common reasons for failed payment KB** If you have tried all of the above and your payment is still failing, you must talk to your bank to understand why they rejected the payment. Cloudflare has documented some common reasons for failed payments in our Troubleshooting Failed Payments guide which can help. If you have attempted all the steps above and your payment is still failing, you must contact your bank to understand the reasons behind the payment rejection. If the issue persists and the reason is unclear, please proceed to submit a ticket for further assistance from the billing team.
Cloudflare Invoices
Questions about Cloudflare Invoices?
If you're having trouble retrieving, updating or understanding your invoice, click Start for guidance.
I purchased a subscription, domain or new feature. When will I receive my invoice?
An invoice will be available on the Billing section of the Cloudflare dashboard within 24 hours.
Could you send me a new invoice with updated billing details?
Any billing updates or changes you have made will apply to all future invoices. Invoices already generated cannot be re-issued.
Where can I access my invoices?

You may download invoices from the Billing section of your Cloudflare account. **Note:** Only the Super Administrators for the account will be able to access invoices via Cloudflare's dashboard. Due to security reasons, we recommend that our customers access their invoices via account dashboard. To manually download your Cloudflare invoices:
  • Log in to your Cloudflare account.
  • Click the **Billing** tab.
  • On the left navigation, click **Invoices**. You will see all invoices associated with your account.
  • Click on the invoice number to Download.
Cloudflare Subscriptions
Looking for a subscription refund?
If you are looking for a refund after upgrading, cancelling or downgrading a subscription, click here to get started.
I have **upgraded** my subscription and am looking for a refund

As soon as you upgrade from any paid subscription our system will automatically calculate and apply a pro-rated credit for the time you didn't use on your previous subscription. To view your current credit balance, visit Payment Info and look for the **Credit Balance** section. **When can I use the credit?** This credit will be automatically applied to your future bills. Credits are valid for 3 years and can be used only for monthly or annual recurring subscriptions. Please note, it cannot be used for new orders or for yearly registrar domain renewals. For more guidance, refer to our Change domain plan guide.
I have **downgraded** my subscription and am looking for a refund

When you downgrade a subscription you will continue to receive the benefits and features of that subscription until the end date. Please note that no credit or refund can be issued in this circumstance. To understand when you will have the service until, visit the Billing > Subscriptions section and under the **Service Status** you should see **Ending On** and the relevant date next to it. You will continue to receive the service related to this subscription until this date. For more guidance, refer to our Cancel Cloudflare Subscriptions and Change domain plan guides.
I have **cancelled** my subscription and am looking for a refund

When you cancel a subscription you will continue to receive the benefits and features of that subscription until the end date. To understand when you will have the service until, visit the Billing > Subscriptions section and under the **Service Status** you should see **Ending On** and the relevant date next to it. You will continue to receive the service related to this subscription until this date. For more guidance, refer to our Cancel Cloudflare Subscriptions and Change domain plan guides.

support.portal.self-help-wizard.ssl: My website isn't working over SSL
support.portal.self-help-wizard.ssl.525: I am seeing a Cloudflare Error 525
### Check your origin server SSL configuration & ciphers To do this: * Ensure that your origin server is accepting TCP connections from Cloudflare on port 443. * Confirm your SSL configuration is compatible with Cloudflare as per our Cipher suites - Origin guide. If you're still seeing Error 525, review our Community Tip for Error 525 or contact your origin server hosting provider.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.ssl.526: I am seeing a Cloudflare Error 526
### Install a valid origin server SSL certificate Your origin serveru2019s certificate is invalid for your site's hostname, expired or not served with the correct intermediate certificate. If you do not know how to resolve this, visit SSL/TLS > Origin Server in the dashboard and follow our deploy an origin CA certificate guide to get a free certificate to install on your origin server. If you cannot install a valid certificate on your origin server, you can downgrade your SSL encryption mode to *Full* instead of *Full (Strict)* as an alternative.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.ssl.othe: I am seeing a different problem or error
Are you seeing a browser / connection error?

Are you seeing a browser connection or SSL error mentioning any of the following terms? 
* NET::ERR_SSL 
* NET::ERR_CERT_ 
* SSL_ERROR_ 
* ERR_SSL 
* Invalid Certificate
Are you seeing a redirect loop?

If you are experiencing a redirect loop, you should see a browser error mentioning any of the following terms: 
* Too Many Redirects 
* This Page isn't redirecting properly 
* ERR_TOO_MANY_REDIRECTS
Are you seeing Mixed Content?
If you are experiencing mixed content, your website will appear broken with missing styling, images or functionality.

### Install Origin CA, set encryption mode to *Full Strict* and/or Enable *Automatic HTTPS Rewrites* Visit the SSL dashboard and check your SSL encryption mode - it should be to be set to *Full* or *Full (Strict)*. If it is not, follow our deploy an origin CA certificate guide to install a valid certificate on your server. Then, set your SSL mode to *Full (Strict)*. If you cannot install a valid certificate on your origin, you can downgrade your SSL mode to *Full* as an alternative. Typically, configuring *Full* or *Full (Strict)* is enough to ensure your origin server also serves links correctly to avoid mixed content. If you still see mixed content and you do not know how to resolve this, you can try enabling Automatic HTTPS Rewrites. Lastly, you can review our troubleshooting mixed content article for more information.
Are you seeing the wrong website displayed?
When visiting your website, do you see a holding page or a completely different website to what you expect?

### Check your DNS is correct and configure your origin server for SSL To do this: 1. Visit the DNS settings for your domain and ensure that the DNS record for your website points to the hostname or IP address for your origin server. If you are unsure of the correct value, contact your origin server hosting provider. 2. Ensure your origin server is enabled to serve your site over HTTPS and Port 443. You can Visit SSL/TLS > Origin Server and follow our deploy an origin CA certificate guide to install a valid certificate on your origin if you need it. If you cannot install a valid certificate on your origin & configure your server for SSL, you can downgrade your SSL mode to *Flexible* however this may cause further issues and you may need to consult our guides troubleshooting mixed content and redirect loops to resolve these.

### Your website appears to be working Based on the answers you have given, your website is working over SSL and your problem is not covered by this wizard. You should go back to the start and check your answers carefully. If you are still having an issue, we recommend reading our SSL/TLS Get Started as well as our SSL Troubleshooting guides for further information.

### Install Origin CA, set SSL encryption mode to *Full Strict* Visit the SSL dashboard and check your SSL encryption mode setting - it should be to be set to *Full (Strict)*. If you encounter an error when loading your website with *Full (Strict)*, visit SSL/TLS > Origin Server and follow our deploy an origin CA certificate guide to install a valid certificate on your server - this will allow you to use *Full (Strict)*. If you cannot install a valid certificate on your origin, you can downgrade your SSL encryption mode to *Full* as an alternative. As a last resort you can choose *Flexible* however if you continue to see redirect loops you will need to fix that issue at your origin server. Read our Too Many Redirects guide for further information.
Is your domain active on Cloudflare's nameservers?
Visit Your Websites and find your domain name. Does it say *Active* underneath the domain name?

### Set your nameservers correctly & check nameservers Visit Overview for your website and follow our setup guide to ensure you update your nameservers correctly. Once you have corrected these, click the *Check nameservers* button on the same page.
Is Universal SSL enabled for your website?
Visit edge certificates and check the Universal SSL setting. If you see a section titled *Disable Universal SSL* then you know that it is currently *Enabled*.
Is your Universal SSL certificate active?

Visit edge certificates - do you see *Active*, *Pending Validation* or another status next to the SSL certificate covering your hostname? Note: typically the certificate covering your hostname will be the wildcard cert e.g. example.com, *.example.com?
Is the hostname proxied?
Visit your DNS settings - do you see *Proxied* next to the domain or subdomain you are seeing the problem with?
Is your hostname covered by an edge certificate?
Visit your DNS settings - do you see a DNS warning 'This hostname is not covered by a certificate' next to the domain or subdomain you are seeing the problem with?

### Your website appears to be working Based on the answers you have given, your website is working over SSL and your problem is not covered by this wizard. You should go back to the start and check your answers carefully. If you are still having an issue, we recommend reading our SSL/TLS Get Started as well as our SSL Troubleshooting guides for further information.

### Toggle Universal SSL To do this: * Visit edge certificates and click *Disable Universal SSL* * Wait 5 minutes and then click *Enable Universal SSL* and wait 15 minutes for your Universal SSL certificate to issue * When the certificate status shows as *Active*, you can test your website again

### Enable Total TLS To do this: 1. Visit edge certificates and click the switch to enable Total TLS 2. When the certificate status for the hostname you are seeing the issue with shows as *Active*, you can test your website again.

Please note that Total TLS requires an Advanced Certificate Manager subscription at $10 per month. As an alternative, you could choose to serve your site over a hostname that is covered by your Free Universal SSL certificate which covers the root domain and all first-level subdomains.

### Set the hostname to proxied To do this: 1. Visit your DNS settings and find the DNS record for your website hostname 2. Click *Edit* and set the Proxy status to *Proxied* 3. Wait 5 minutes and then test again
Is your Universal SSL certificate *Pending Validation*?

Visit edge certificates - do you see u201CPending Validationu201D or another status next to the SSL certificate covering your hostname? Note: typically this will be the wildcard cert e.g. example.com, *.example.com
Does your domain have invalid DNSSEC?

To check this: * Visit letsdebug.net and enter your domain name * Choose *DNS-01* and click *Run Test* Once the test has completed, do you see a warning as in this example mentioning *DNSLookupFailed* and *fatal DNSSEC issues*?

### Fix your invalid DNSSEC Your domainu2019s DNSSEC is broken at your domain registrar - a registrar is the company that you pay for your domain registration. To fix this: 1. Follow our guide to Enable DNSSEC on Cloudflare to fix this. 2. Test your domain again using letsdebug.net to ensure the *fatal DNSSEC issues* message is removed 3. Visit the edge certificates dashboard and click *Disable Universal SSL*, wait 5 minutes and click *Enable Universal SSL* again - the certificate should become *Active* within around 15 minutes

### Toggle Universal SSL To do this: * Visit edge certificates and click *Disable Universal SSL* * Wait 5 minutes and then click *Enable Universal SSL* and wait 15 minutes for your Universal SSL certificate to issue * When the certificate status shows as *Active*, you can test your website again

### Toggle Universal SSL To do this: * Visit edge certificates and click *Disable Universal SSL* * Wait 5 minutes and then click *Enable Universal SSL* and wait 15 minutes for your Universal SSL certificate to issue * When the certificate status shows as *Active*, you can test your website again

### Enable Universal SSL for your website To do this: * Visit edge certificates and click the *Enable Universal SSL* button * Wait around 15 minutes for your Universal SSL certificate to issue * When the certificate status shows as *Active*, you can test your website again
support.portal.self-help-wizard.registra: Transferring a domain to Cloudflare Registrar
Having trouble starting or completing your transfer to Cloudflare Registrar?
If you cannot start your transfer or your transfer has not completed, check here for immediate answers.
Why do I see **"transfer conditions not met"** or no option to transfer my domain to Cloudflare?

Why do I see u201Ctransfer conditions not metu201D or no option to transfer my domain to Cloudflare? **1. Check your domain TLD is supported** Registrar only supports specific Top Level Domains (TLD). Visit TLD Policies - if your TLD is not listed as available, you cannot use Cloudflare as your domain Registrar at this time. Cloudflare Support is unable to confirm when a specific TLD will go live. **2. Check your domain name is supported** *Registrar does not support Premium domains*. To check if your domain is premium, enter your domain into Google Domains Search - if you see the Premium label, you cannot use Cloudflare as your domain Registrar at this time. *Registrar does not support Internalionalisted Domain Names (IDNs).* Does your domain name start with `xn--`? Currently, Internationalised Domain Names (IDNs) are not supported and you cannot use Cloudflare as your domain Registrar at this time. **3. Check the domain expiry** If your domain is due to expire within 15 days (or within 10 days for `.uk` TLDs), you must first renew the domain at your current domain registrar. Once you have done this, you can then transfer to Cloudflare Registrar. **4. Check the domain is Active with Cloudflare** The domain must be added to your Cloudflare account already and have a status of u201CActiveu201D. Visit the Dashboard - if you do not see `Active` underneath your domain name, click the domain name and follow the on screen instructions. Once the domain is Active, you can start the Registrar transfer process with Cloudflare. **5. Check the domain's WHOIS status** Visit a WHOIS service such as who.is and check the Status field. You will not be able to start a transfer to another Registrar if you see any of the following listed: * clientTransferProhibited * serverTransferProhibited * serverHold You must contact your current Registrar to ensure these statuses are removed before you can start a transfer to Cloudflare Registrar. **6. Check you have a valid credit card on file** Visit Payment info and ensure a working payment method is entered. You should also review our Registrar Get Started guide and FAQ. Note: Our Registrar support team can only assist if all of the above have been checked by you. If all of these checks look good and you still see `transfer conditions not met` and cannot start the transfer process, please close this and click the `Add more details` to raise a ticket with the Cloudflare Support team.
I cannot change my nameservers to Cloudflare at my current registrar

You will be unable to transfer a domain to Cloudflare Registrar unless nameservers are set correctly to the ones designated in your Cloudflare account.

If your current registrar does not permit changes to 3rd party nameservers before starting a transfer, you cannot use Cloudflare Registrar at this time.
Why is my domain transfer stuck in **"Transfer In Progress"**?

This means that your request has been submitted by Cloudflare to your previous registrar. The process can take up to 5 days - please wait until then. 

To help speed things up - if after 24 hours you continue to see this status, try:

* **Contact your current registrar** and confirm the domain has been unlocked
* **Disable WHOIS privacy** at your current registrar

If the status is still present after 5 days, you should contact Cloudflare support for additional guidance. Please note Cloudflare Support will be unable to assist until you have attempted all of the above and waited 5 days.
Why is my domain transfer stuck in **"Pending approval"**?

This means that your transfer request is with your current Registrar - it can take them up to 5 days to release the domain.

To move faster, you can contact your current Registrar or log in to their dashboard to see if you can manually approve it. Cloudflare cannot speed up this process, so you must contact your current Registrar to assist further. 

If you are still seeing this status 5 days after confirming the domain is released you should contact Cloudflare support for additional guidance. Please note Cloudflare Support will be unable to assist until you have attempted all of the above and waited 5 days.
This means that you or your registrar may have canceled the transfer request. You can visit the Transfer Domains page and select **Retry** to initiate a new transfer request.
Why is my auth code not working?

If your authorisation code is not being accepted, try the following: * Open an incognito mode or private browser, log in to the Cloudflare dashboard and try again. * **Do not** copy & paste the code as it may be including hidden characters and spaces. Carefully re-type the auth code exactly including the correct case for each character. * If the issue persists, contact your registrar and ask for a new code - only your current registrar can confirm & provide the correct code.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.zt_acces: Having errors or issues with Access?
Answer some questions to get your Access configuration working correctly.
I'm having trouble with Access
What issue are you seeing?
Select the option for your issue that relates to the most common problems. DESCRIPTIOn
I need help with authenticating through Access
I need help with configuring an Application behind Access
Are you setting up a new Application?
Are you trying to set up Single Sign-on(SSO) for the Cloudflare dashboard?
You can configure your Identity Provider to make Single Sign-on requests to SaaS apps, as well as the Cloudflare Dashboard.

Dashboard SSO is an Enterprise-only feature at this time. If you are an Enterprise customer, please follow the steps to configure your Identity Provider outlined on the Developer Documents and reach out to your Customer Success Manager for the next steps.
Are you configuring a SaaS Application
For SaaS Applications, please follow the Add A SaaS Application documentation for the most common SaaS Application configurations.
For Self-Hosted Applications, please follow the Add a Self-Hosted Application documentation for how to configure a self-hosted application.
Are you having trouble with configuring a posture rule?

With Cloudflare Zero Trust, you can configure Zero Trust policies that rely on additional signals from the WARP client or from third-party endpoint security providers. Find out more about Device Posture on the Access Integrations page.

Please check the device posture documentation for the specific posture check you're setting up to make sure your OS and WARP mode meet the requirements. You can also review the information in the Logs > Posture to see what the expected vs. received values were for each check. If you need to submit a ticket, please make sure you include WARP debug logs.

Please contact Support with your Application ID and description of the issue you're having with as much detail as possible.  Please include what's going wrong vs. what the expected behavior is, and how you're replicating the problem, so our Support team can better assist you.
Are you using an Identity Provider (IdP)?
Okta, Azure AD, and Google are common Identity Providers.
Do you see an error that says 'Failed to fetch user/group information from the Identity Provider'?

This is an indication that the communication between Cloudflare and your Identify Provider has broken, and your IdP isn't sending us the information that we expect. Please check your configuration, using the Identity Provider Integration documentation for you IdP on both ends, paying particular attention to any secrets, etc. that could have expired.
Is the user receiving an unexpected decision?
For example, a blocked request might be due to a misconfigured policy.

Please review the decisions in Logs > Access. For blocks, you'll be able to see why they didn't pass for each policy. Additionally, you can test your policy directly in the Cloudflare One Dashboard. See the Policy Management Developer Documents for more details.
Please submit a support ticket containing as much information as possible.  Please include the App ID, what's going wrong vs. what the expected behavior is, and how you're replicating the problem.
Is this an issue with One-Time PINs (OTP)?
Short-lived 6-digit codes are sent to the email in the Access policy.

Please note that OTPs will only be sent if the user passes the policies. Therefore, please check they have access to the app. If you need to submit a ticket, please provide the user email, the App ID, and a HAR file of the login attempt.
Is this an issue with service authentication, eg: service tokens?
Service tokens can be used to authenticate machines not listed by the Identity Provider
Are you using a service token?
Please ensure the token has been added to a policy with the 'Service Auth' action.  It will not work as expected with an 'Allow' or 'Bypass' action.

If you're using mTLS, please ensure you have added the correct associated hostname to the certificate, by reviewing how to generate a client certificate on the Developer Documents. If you are facing a problem with something else, please submit a ticket with the exact issue and how you are replicating it.
Please submit a support ticket containing as much information as possible.  Please include the App ID, what's going wrong vs. what the expected behavior is, and how you're replicating the problem.
Having errors or issues configuring the Zero Trust WARP Client?
Answer some questions to get your WARP client up and running immediately.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.zt_warp: I'm having trouble configuring the WARP Client
What issue are you seeing? DESCRIPTIOn
When turning on the WARP Client, did all traffic to websites or apps stop working?

Some apps like Forcepoint and Mcafee Antivirus can take over a machine's DNS resolution, preventing the WARP Client from connecting to the Cloudflare edge. Try changing the machine's DNS resolver to 1.1.1.1/1.0.0.1, or configure your local firewall to allow the outbound connection.
When turning on the WARP Client, did specific websites or apps stop working?

You may need to configure a Split Tunnel or Local Domain Fallback so that the website or app's traffic is excluded from the WARP Client DNS resolution. If you need the traffic to come through Cloudflare's network, an alternate option is to configure a Gateway Rule for the website or application and set the action to 'Do Not Inspect'. Please take a look at our FAQ section, which might address the issue you're having.
Are you able to reproduce this on the most current version of the WARP Client?
Please upgrade to the latest WARP Client. We are constantly making improvements to the client and in many cases, a simple upgrade can fix the issues you're seeing.
